title: Chipping Norton Walks

images.title: John Pridham / Chipping Norton Almshouses
images.caption: A pretty row of Almshouses, Church Street. An inscription on the almshouses records that they were founded in 1640 as "The work and gift of Henry Cornish, gent".

images.title: Jonathan Billinger / The Leys, Chipping Norton
images.caption: The Leys, Chipping Norton. A residential road leading downhill to the Bliss Mill.

images.title: David Stowell / Chipping Norton Guildhall
images.caption: The Guildhall. Part of it is now the Visitor Information Centre.

images.title: Steve Daniels / Chipping Norton Common
images.caption: View across Chipping Norton Common with Biss Mill in the background. The mill used to manufacture tweed and is now a Grade II listed building. The impressive structure was built in 1872 for cloth manufacturer William Bliss, to make fine tweed cloth from locally produced wool. It was designed by the architect George Woodhouse of Bolton, who also designed mills in Lancashire, including Victoria Mill in Miles Platting; Woodhouse was also involved in the construction of Bolton Town Hall. The mill closed in 1980 and was converted into residential apartments in around 1988.

images.title: Parish church, Chipping Norton by Colin Park, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Parish church

images.title: David Martin / Chipping Norton Town Hall
images.caption: The Town Hall

description: This popular Oxfordshire market town is a great base for exploring the Cotswold Hills. This long circular walk makes use of three long distance waymarked trails which run through the area surrounding the town. You will follow sections of the Wychwood Way, the Shakespeare's Way and the D'arcy Dalton Way to visit a series of pretty villages including Cornwell, Churchill, Shipton Under Wychwood, Ascott-under-Wychwood and Chadlington.
